awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Industrial Mathematics and Statistics
awd_abstract_narration:
The Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI) REU in Industrial Mathematics and Statistics provides a distinctive educational experience for students in the mathematical sciences by introducing them to the ways in which mathematicians and statisticians use math in the "real world". Students work in teams on research problems of industrial and mathematical significance that come directly from industry and that are of immediate interest to the companies involved in the program.  Students work closely with company representatives to define the problem and to develop solutions. They work closely with faculty advisors to maintain a clear focus on the mathematics and statistics at the core of the project. This summer research provides challenges not faced in traditional undergraduate programs and helps to develop skills usually not addressed in academic programs. It also provides a glimpse of some of the many career possibilities that are open to students with a strong mathematical background.

This REU supports 9 undergraduate students for 9 weeks during the summer on 2 to 3 different industrial projects.  Students develop a project goals statement in the first week, in collaboration with a faculty advisor and a company liaison.  Over the next seven weeks, students conduct the actual research while presenting their progress to both an academic audience at WPI and a corporate audience at the sponsoring company.  In the final week, students give their final oral presentations at WPI and the company and submit a written report. Professional development activities presenting mathematical career options in academia and industry complement the program.  The selection process focuses on students with a strong academic background but with limited opportunities for research in mathematics at their home institutions.  One selection emphasis is an openness to pursue a range of research directions which an industrial problem may require. Successful research teams have been multifaceted and diverse, and therefore members of underrepresented groups in the mathematical sciences are especially encouraged to apply.

por.por_cntn:
The 2018-2022 WPI REU Program in Industrial Mathematics and Statistics provided a unique educational experience for students of mathematics and statistics by introducing them to research on real-world problems that come directly from businesses and industry. Students worked closely with a company representative to define the problem and to develop solutions of value to the company. The students met daily with a faculty advisor to formulate the problem mathematically and maintain a clear focus on the mathematics at the core of the project. The industrial problems rarely fit into one area of mathematics and this fact has been an important part of the research experience. The projects called upon analysis techniques, modelling, statistics, optimization, and computer programming.

Eleven faculty members advised 27 students over the four years the program ran, including 16 women and 5 members of racial/ethnic groups underrepresented in mathematics. Results from the projects directly impact R&D at the companies and the relevant mathematical sciences fields. Seven research projects were completed on projects focusing on ecology, finance, medical research, manufacturing, and geothermal heating:

- Modeling the Spatio-Temporal Dynamics of Interacting Fish Species in the with NOAA-Northeast Fisheries Center: Built spatio-temporal population models for single- and multiple-species of Atlantic Cod and Atlantic Herring in the Northeast Continental Shelf.  The group employed statistical approaches such as nonlinear filtering to estimate model parameters and to quantify uncertainty in model predictions, comparing the results to trawling data.  Presented work at the School for Marine Science and Technology, University of Massachusetts-Dartmouth, Dartmouth, MA, the 2019 Joint Mathematics Meeting (JMM) in Baltimore, MD and at the Women in Mathematics in New England (WIMIN) Conference at Northampton, MA.

 - Pricing TYVIX Options Using a Risk-Neutralized Historical Distribution with Doherty Advisors, LLC:   Built pricing model for exchange-traded VIX options, validated using current market prices and then extended the model to TYVIX options.  Presented work at the 2019 Joint Mathematics Meeting (JMM) in Baltimore, MD and at the Women in Mathematics in New England (WIMIN) Conference at Northampton, MA.

- Extending the Systems Model of Platelet Homeostasis to Understand Platelet Dynamics in Immune Thrombocytopenia Purpura with Pfizer, Inc.: Explored an ordinary differential equations model of platelet homeostasis in healthy individuals to include macrophage dynamics that result in accelerated platelet destruction. Presented work at the 2020 Joint Mathematics Meeting (JMM) in Denver, CO.

- Material Wear Data Analysis with General Electric Aviation: Extracted features of materials data most critical to the overall wear to construct predictive models to find the most effective and efficient material combinations and to provide more insight on future experimental procedures. Work presented at General Electric Aviation, Dayton, OH, the NYC Regional Math Alliance Conference, City College of New York, New York, NY, the Research for Undergraduates Symposium, Council of Undergraduate Research, Arlington, VA, and the 2020 Joint Mathematics Meeting (JMM) in Denver, CO.

- Extension of the Human Blood Coagulation Model to Understand the Role of C1-Inhibitor in Hereditary Angioedema with Pfizer, Inc.:  Extended an ordinary differential equations model on coagulation to include the dynamics of the C1-INH protein.  Presented work at the 2020 Joint Mathematics Meeting (JMM) in Denver, CO.

- Modeling SARS-CoV-2 to Predict its Effect on Patients with End-Stage Renal Disease with State Street with Renal Research Institute: Developed population-level spread of SARS-CoV-2 to which includes mitigation strategies, and a virus dynamics model at the patient level.  The student team was preparing posters for the 2022 Joint Mathematics Meeting in Seattle, WA, but this event was postponed one month prior to the event.

- Decorrelation Detection in a Financial Time Series Data Set with Wellington Management:  Dimensional estimation techniques are used to determine whether seemingly diversified index fund portfolios have latent commonalities that increase risk for investors. The student team was preparing posters for the 2022 Joint Mathematics Meeting in Seattle, WA, but this event was postponed one month prior to the event.

- Optimizing Efficiencies in an Electromagnetic Heat Exchanger with Air Force Research Laboratory-Kirtland AFB:  Optimization methods are applied to electromagnetic energy absorption found in two different material configurations. Presented at the 2023 Joint Mathematics Meetings (JMM) in Boston, MA and at Women in Mathematics in New England (WIMIN) Conference at Northampton, MA in 2022.

The program developed the students' oral and written communication skills so that they can communicate their results effectively in industrial and academic settings. The students visited their industrial partners and other companies and were exposed to the sort of work that non-academic mathematicians and statisticians do. The program also provided opportunities for the students to get non-technical professional development from experts.
